item.title: Mindfulness
item.description:
I recently participated for the first time in a silent retreat (6 hrs) as part of a Mindfulness-Based Stress Reduction course. Iâ€™ve really been enjoying this course and the experience of learning new ways (for me) to live better and enjoy life more. If you havenâ€™t heard of mindfulness before (like me a few months ago), Wikipedia defines it as:

Mindfulness is the psychological process of bringing one's attention to
experiences occurring in the present moment, which can be developed
through the practice of meditation and other training.

In academia and science, but really anywhere, we can encounter many sources of stress (some examples below). We all deal with it in different ways and this MBSR course is just one that Iâ€™m liking right now and recommend. If thereâ€™s no course near you, check out the Full Catastrophe Living book that my course is based on1.

All these tweets are threads, so youâ€™ll have to open them to see them: click on the blue bird on the right side of each tweet.

I won an NSF grant yesterday, with three weeks to go before applying to tenure.

A threadðŸ‘‡

— Dr. Bryony DuPont (@BryonyDuPont) June 10, 2018

Just another barrier that us scientists in #developing #countries need to find ways to overcome. Not only do we have less funding, but also generating data that for other countries is routine is more expensive. #latin #american #scientists #plight https://t.co/Hln7N4x4iM

— Daniela Robles (@daniela_oaks) June 7, 2018

Thanks for sharing this Ted! @tladeras As with anything, but particularly with mental health, I think itâ€™s important to know you are not alone and that some things we feel have names: impostor syndrome, anxiety, depression, etc. Our minds are very powerful! #MentalHealthMatters https://t.co/X1UIAznV8f

— L. Collado-Torres (@fellgernon) June 6, 2018

One of the exercises on our silent retreat was mindful eating. That is, eating slowly and focusing on our senses while eating food. This involved smelling the food, seeing all the colors it has, feeling all the different textures, and focusing on its taste. Plus, not talking to anyone. I had bought a lunch before the retreat (so I wouldnâ€™t have to break the silence during it) that I normally donâ€™t find interesting: some fruit and a chicken curry wrap from CVS. But wow, it was amazing that day! I greatly enjoyed how it tasted and all the different sensations I felt. I couldnâ€™t believe it was the same food I had eaten other times before without much excitement.

Lately Iâ€™ve been processing some strong feelings related to feeling unwelcome, homesickness and loneliness. Iâ€™m doing many things that I know help me, starting with talking about them with my family. Iâ€™ve also been keeping myself busy doing some sports outside, going to events, bars, having friends over, etc. But what motivated me to write this post today is that after lunch I left really bad today. I had to go outside and try to calm myself.

I thought I did, returned to work, and nah, I couldnâ€™t do it today. So I went home, rested in my room in the dark, and I find myself finishing this post about 2 hours later. Iâ€™m not sure itâ€™s related to the MSBR course, but Iâ€™m wondering if the mindfulness practice is also opening my mindâ€™s ears and eyes to my inner feelings way more than normal2. I donâ€™t think itâ€™s bad. Itâ€™s just that itâ€™s way harder to enjoy this process than it was eating a lunch. Iâ€™m trying to feel happy because I have feelings and Iâ€™m recognizing them. My family is also happy because they view it as a part of maturing and that Iâ€™m getting ready for taking another step in my life.

Just some things are taking me way more time than normal. For example, it took me 2 days to process what I wanted to reply to a tweet and how to word it: it turned out well because I think we all heard each other ^^.

Thanks for the link @apreshill! I agree that the blog post was aweful! You canâ€™t blame X for the fact that X is marginalized. However, I disagree with the notion that Z canâ€™t talk about X (challenging). Iâ€™m in favor of inclusion. Otherwise that line of thought leads to xenophobia

— L. Collado-Torres (@fellgernon) June 11, 2018

I also discovered that the silent retreat reminded me of vacations where I turn off my phone/email and spend a few days thinking about whatâ€™s next. I used to go to Mexico every 6 months or so during my PhD to recharge. I want to do it again, but I canâ€™t. That lead me to my strong feelings of homesickness I had today.

Just to close, Iâ€™m OK. I appreciate all the support I have and I recommend others to learn about mindfulness. You might be missing out some super tasty lunches and/or an exploration trip towards your inner self.

I also want to add that I know some of you might see this post as over-sharing (yes, it might be). One reply is that I think that leaders also have to show their vulnerable sides. This has been debated a lot in academic twitter accounts in the context of showing your failures too, not just your successes.

item.title: Homepage photos: which cheek you show says something?
item.description:
John Bohannon wroteÂ Scientists’ Photos Reveal Their Inner Mr. SpockÂ which I found funny in a science-curious kind of way. I hadn’t thought about the message you could be sending depending on which cheek you show. I had only noticed that people like to show more serious-looking photos of themselves and sometimes make it an obviously funny one. I have to say too that some of the pages from my co-workers don’t even show a picture. I guess that’s a more recent trend to make it more “professional” looking. Dunno.

I have to guess that dead center-looking pictures are rare. At least when you look at Rachael Jack’s one it stands out. It reminds me of passport pictures. For my new academic site I choose one that doesn’t look serious, I wanted a fun one! Plus I make it obvious which country I’m from ^^.

For some reason this doesn’t surprise me:

>

while English language and literature scholars showed the left cheek and engineers showed the right, psychologists were more difficult to categorize.Â

item.title: Is science cool?
item.description:
Adam Ruben shares his answer to whether science is cool or not. Since “cool” depends on the current trends, this question is set on the recent landing of Curiosity. It’s the landrover that recently landed on Mars and has been sending some pictures back.Â 

Anyhow, check his answer here. I liked this part:

>

If the Mars landing draws students to science, it wonâ€™t be because they witnessed science doing something cool. Itâ€™ll be because they witnessed science doing something human, something genuine, something legitimately appealing on its own merits. Something scientific.

Picture taken from his commentary piece.
